DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma Nuclear Grade Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term for the nuclear grade of invasive breast cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Text terms to describe the nuclear grade of invasive breast cancer.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women. --2003

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to the nucleus.:A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: ECOG CRF:Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group Case Report Form

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the nuclear grade category for the breast tumor in the patient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree or intensity or amount.: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

Concepts.definition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.

Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

Concepts.definition: An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.
